name: Rainelys Francisco
comment info:
What do you notice?
     I notice that male college athletes usually make much more money than women college athletes in major sports. Men that specialize in the basketball makeover $600K and $400k+ in football. On the other hand, women in the basketball and baseball field make less than $200K, showing a very distant outlier when comparing these two graphs. On the other hand, when looking at the "non-revenue" sports chart, women still make less than men. What's the real reason behind this?

    Why do women, regardless of playing major and non-revenue sports, make so much less than men? Is there any sort of sexism behind this? Do women have "less" skill than men? 
    
    How does this relate to you and your community?
    This relates to me and any women that decide to pursue their career in a sport. Women over many years have been knocked down and underestimated when being compared to men, especially in the sports field. Female active skills are often under-viewed and not well appreciated, considering the fact that most viewed sports are aggressive and are "most suited for men." The large outlier and decrease in earnings for women compared to men can knockdown future generations (and even current) hope for gaining their deserved recognition in sports. Why are women  underestimated in sports?
    
    Headline
    "Get On The Field!: Does Your Gender Affect Your Sports Earnings?"

name: Reid Giribaldi
comment info:
1. This graph depicts the average earnings of college athletes involved in a various range of sports. I noticed that the left side of the graph, with only four sports, conveys far greater earnings than any sports listed on the right-hand graph. I was surprised that women's sports were pretty concentrated near the top on the right-hand graph. I was really happy to see this, as I have always felt like female sports don't usually get the love that they deserve. On a similar note, I found it interesting that women's basketball was on the left-hand of the graph (earning a much higher amount). While it is still significantly lower than men's basketball, it is a very high earning for a college athlete, and I was unaware that their earnings were so much higher than that of a majority of men's college sports like track or ice hockey.
    2. I wonder why men's soccer is so low. Every time the World Cup comes around, the world becomes infatuated with male soccer players such as Messi or Ronaldo. For that reason, I find it surprising that men's soccer at the college level is relatively unpopular. 
    3. This relates to me as a senior in high school because while I am not personally an athlete, I have a lot of classmates and peers announcing their commitments to further their athletic careers in their college endeavors. I found this a very interesting statistic to look at, given I might know a person or two who will contribute to these numbers one day.
    4. College Athletes: Is the Work Worth it?

name: Lily AOSE
comment info:
This graph analyzes the earnings of college athletes in both major revenue sports and non-revenue sports. The major revenue sports, which include men's basketball, football, baseball, and women's basketball, show a significant pay gap between men and women, with men’s basketball earning much more than women’s basketball. In contrast, on the non-revenue side, men’s golf stands out as the highest-earning non-revenue sport, even though it doesn’t generate nearly as much revenue as the major sports. Women's gymnastics earns much more than men’s gymnastics, and men’s and women’s track and cross-country sports are on the rise in earnings, largely due to increased exposure from the Olympics. Fencing, on the other hand, generates the least revenue of all the sports listed. I wonder why softball, which is often considered the counterpart to baseball, is classified as a non-revenue sport while baseball is a major sport. I also wonder how the earnings of these sports have changed over time and if the financial gap between men’s and women’s sports will continue to persist as women’s sports gain more exposure. Additionally, I wonder how increased media coverage and sponsorship deals have influenced the revenue disparity. This graph is relevant to my community because college sports are widely followed, and this analysis offers a new perspective on how these athletes are compensated.
    Headline: The Financial Divide in College Sports

name: Johan P3
comment info:
1)The image presents two bar charts comparing the average earnings of college athletes in major and nonrevenue sports. In major sports, men's basketball players earn the most, averaging nearly $600,000, followed by football players with substantial but lower earnings. Women's basketball earnings are significantly lower than their male counterparts, and baseball players earn the least among major sports. In nonrevenue sports, men's golf leads in earnings, followed by women's gymnastics, while wrestling and both men's and women's track/cross country saw notable increases, attributed to Olympic exposure. However, earnings in nonrevenue sports remain significantly lower than in major sports, with the highest reaching around $20,000.
    2)I wonder what factors contribute most to the earnings differences between sports. Is it primarily media exposure, sponsorship deals, or social media influence?
    3) New Jersey has a strong sports culture, with major college athletic programs like Rutgers University and Seton Hall, where athletes may experience similar earning trends. If you're a student-athlete or know one, understanding these earnings disparities could influence decisions about which sports to pursue, how to leverage NIL deals, or how to maximize financial opportunities.
    4)Show Me the Money! College Athletes Are Cashing In—But Who’s Winning?

replies.comment info:
